questions.text: The hormone produced and released by the cell at the tip of the arrow binds to receptors on the surface of which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteoclast

 

The cell at the tip of the arrow is a parathyroid chief cell, which produces parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH ultimately acts to increase blood calcium by stimulating osteoclasts—cells responsible for bone resorption.

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) binds to receptors (via the RANK/RANKL pathway, indirectly mediated by osteoblasts) that activate osteoclasts, leading to increased bone resorption.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoblasts: Osteoblasts possess PTH receptors. PTH binding induces them to express RANKL, stimulating osteoclast differentiation. They do not resorb bone directly; they build bone matrix.

 

Option B. Chondrocytes: Chondrocytes are cartilage cells involved in cartilage formation/growth. 

 

Option C. Osteocytes: Osteocytes are mature bone cells embedded in bone matrix, functioning in bone maintenance and mineral homeostasis. They do not express PTH receptors for bone resorption.

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage?
A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition?

A 52-year-old female patient present with 4 cm diameter diagnosed breast cancer lesion with ipsilateral axillary and contralateral supraclavicular lymphadenopathy as shown below. As per AJCC system, patient belongs to which stage of breast cancer?

choices.text: Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty, meatal advancement
Chordee correction, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty
Meatal advancement, chordee correction, glanuloplasty, urethral mobilization
Glanuloplasty, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, chordee correction

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for correction of hypospadias surgery?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty, meatal advancement

questions.text: Match the suture with the most likely indication:
questions.solution: Ans. B) A-1, B-3, C-2, D-4

choices.text: Given data inadequate for calculation of class intervals

questions.text: What will be the 95% confidence interval (CI) for an estimated prevalence of 10% and a sample size of 100?
An orthopedic resident has removed a K-wire from the fractured SCH of a 13-year-old boy. Where should he discard this?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cardboard box with blue marking

choices.text: X1B, 1 lakh IU vit A
X1A, 2 lakh IU vit A
X1B, 2 lakh IU vit A

questions.text: A 2-year-old child comes with the following finding. Identify the grade and management:
questions.solution: Ans. D) X1B, 2 lakh IU vit A

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding sodalime?

 

  1. 100 g of sodalime can absorb 23 liters of CO2
  2. Amsorb is preferred for Sevoflurane and Desflurane over sodalime 
  3. The major constituent of sodalime is Ca (OH)2
  4. Water content of sodalime is 5%
  5. Can form a neurotoxic compound with Trilene
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 5

 

Statement 1. 100 g of soda lime can absorb 23 liters of CO₂: True. this is an approximate value for fresh soda lime capacity.

 

Statement 2. Amsorb is preferred for Sevoflurane and Desflurane over soda lime: True. standard soda lime can react with sevoflurane/desflurane to produce toxic compounds (Compound A); Amsorb avoids this.

 

Statement 3. Major constituent of soda lime is Ca(OH)₂: True. calcium hydroxide is the main active component for CO₂ absorption.

 

Statement 5. Can form a neurotoxic compound with Trilene: True – soda lime can react with trichloroethylene (Trilene) producing potentially neurotoxic byproducts.

 

Incorrect Statement:

 

Statement 4. Water content of soda lime is 5%: False. actual water content is 13–20%, which is required for efficient CO₂ absorption.

questions.text:
Identify the layer involved in the following disease:

 

  1. Pemphigus foliaceous

  2. Icthyosis

  3. Pemphigus vulgaris

  4. LCH

  5. Vitiligo

Identify the correct statements:

  1. Direct observation with a structured checklist is the best method to survey the injection practices of health workers.
  2. Mass drug administration done for Worm infestation, Vitamin A deficiency and Scabies.
  3. Innermost circle of Rule of haves denotes hypertensives getting treatment.
  4. Type A PHCs have >20deliveries per month
What is the appropriate size for ET tube for child aged 8?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 6mm

 

ET tube size in children can be estimated using the age-based formula (uncuffed tube):

 

  • Internal diameter (mm)=[4/Age in years]​+4

 

Here, for a 8yr child, 8/4+4=6mm

 

  • This size ensures adequate ventilation while minimizing the risk of airway trauma.
  • Cuffed tubes may require 0.5 mm smaller size compared to uncuffed tubes.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman, gravida 1 para 0, at 36 weeks gestation is sent to the hospital for a blood pressure of 190/110 mm Hg in the office. The patient was prescribed insulin therapy for gestational diabetes at 28 weeks gestation but has been poorly compliant. On arrival, her blood pressure is 184/106 mm Hg. Initial laboratory results show elevated serum creatinine and transaminases. Blood glucose is 204 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria. Nifedipine, magnesium sulfate, and insulin are administered. Induction of labor is started with oxytocin. Six hours later, the patient's blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. The patient now complaints of nausea, headache, generalized muscle weakness and respiratory distress. DTRs are absent. What is the likely cause of the findings?

A young female presented to you with primary amenorrhea. Examination reveals normal breast development and absent axillary and pubic hairs. Pelvic examination shows a normally developed vagina with clitoromegaly and micro-phallus. On ultrasound, masses are visible in the inguinal region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Partial androgen insensitivity syndrome

choices.text: The shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet is the obstetric conjugate.
Diagonal conjugate is measured from tip of sacral promontory to the lower margin of pubic symphysis.
Obstetric conjugate is calculated by subtracting 1.5 cm from diagonal conjugate.
Contracted pelvis is defined as transverse diameter <10cm and AP diameter <12cm.

questions.text: All of the following are true except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Contracted pelvis is defined as transverse diameter <10 cm and AP diameter <12 cm

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order:

  1. MSAFP, E3, HCG, Inhibin-A
  2. TIFA scan
  3. Growth-Liquor scan
  4. NT-NB

A pregnant woman with G3P2L0 presented to you with a pregnancy at period of gestation of 9 weeks, She has a history of conization one year back currently on follow-up with no recurrence on PAP smear. She also has the history of preterm births at 30 weeks during her last pregnancy. What is your next step in the management of this patient?

A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks +5 days gestation for induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 1 cm dilated and 30% effaced. The vertex is at -1 station and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the modified Bishop score for this lady?

choices.text: Placenta previa should be ruled out
Uterine diadelphys is likely in the patient
There are high chances of cord prolapse in the patient

questions.text: A multiparous woman is in labor at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination, the uterus appears asymmetrical. In fundal grip, the fetal pole is not palpable and in pelvic grip, the lower pole of the uterus is empty. All of the following are true about the given presentation except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Uterine diadelphys is likely in the patient

questions.text:
31-year-old woman comes to the AIIMS OPD due to a 6.8-kg weight gain over the last few months. She has been unable to lose weight despite rigorous dieting and regular exercise. The patient also has experienced weakness and cannot lift weights that she was able to lift before the onset of her symptoms. Her menstrual periods have been irregular for the last few months, and she has had increasing anxiety and insomnia for which she has started seeing a clinical psychologist.  On examination, blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and pulse is 88/min and regular. Neurologic examination shows proximal muscle weakness. Dark terminal hair is present on the lower abdomen. Fasting laboratory results are as follows.

 

Glucose-130 mg/dL

 

Sodium-142 mEq/L

 

Potassium-3.6 mEq/L

 

Chloride-98 mEq/L

 

Bicarbonate-28 mEq/L

 

Calcium-9.2 mg/dL

 

TSH-2.2 mlU/L (N-0.5 to 5.0 mIU/L)

 

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test

questions.text:
52-year-old woman with known liver cirrhosis comes to the emergency department with bright bleeding per rectum for 2 days. She also has increasing abdominal distension and discomfort. The patient has been on daily furosemide and spironolactone as well as water and sodium restriction. She had variceal banding after an episode of esophageal bleeding due to esophageal varices 3 months ago. There is 2+ peripheral pitting edema. Laboratory results as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL

 

Leukocytes: 4,200/mm3

 

Blood urea nitrogen: 72 mg/dL

 

Serum creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL

 

Urine sodium: 9meq/l (N-20-220meq/l)

 

No urinary casts

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acute kidney injury?

choices.text: Central adrenal insufficiency from glucocorticoid use

questions.text: 38-year-old woman comes to the office with a 3-week history of weight loss, nausea, abdominal pain, and postural dizziness. She travelled to Thailand 6 months ago and has felt fatigued since then. Medical history is notable for moderate persistent asthma treated with an inhaled beta-2 agonist and inhaled corticosteroid. Over the last 2 years, the patient has had several asthma exacerbations requiring oral prednisone. She also has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. The patient is married and is a stay-at-home mother. Blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and pulse is 96/min. Skin examination shows increased pigmentation at the palmar creases and mucous membranes. Initial laboratory testing shows mild hyponatremia and hyperkalaemia with normal renal function Complete blood count is normal, but differential shows moderate eosinophilia. Follow-up testing confirms a low 8AM serum cortisol. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Granulomatous infiltration of adrenal

questions.text: 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department with light-headedness and generalized weakness for the last 2 days. He has chronic stable angina with exertion. However, over the last 2 days he has also had occasional chest discomfort at rest. The patient's medical problems include hypertension and bronchial asthma. He has no shortness of breath, cough, or peripheral edema. His only medications are aspirin and isosorbide dinitrate. Blood pressure is 105/66 mmHg. Electrocardiogram obtained in the emergency department is shown here. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac pacing

 

The ECG shows complete heart block (third-degree AV block) with regular P waves and independent, slow, wide QRS complexes. In a symptomatic patient—especially with light-headedness, weakness, and low blood pressure—this is an indication for urgent cardiac pacing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenosine: Used for supraventricular tachycardias, not for bradyarrhythmias or heart block; would worsen conduction block here.

 

Option C. Digoxin: Can exacerbate AV block by further slowing conduction—contraindicated in complete heart block.

 

Option D. Fibrinolytic therapy: Indicated for acute ST-elevation myocardial infarction, not for bradyarrhythmias without evidence of infarction on ECG.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man comes to the OPD due to a one-month history of progressive dyspnoea, generalized weakness, fatigue, and palpitations. He also reports tingling and numbness in both lower limbs. His daughter adds that since his wife's death a year ago, the patient has not been taking care of himself. Blood pressure is 105/50 mm Hg and pulse is 104/ min. Cardiovascular examination shows a displaced apical impulse at the sixth intercostal space, a third heart sound, and high-volume, collapsing carotid pulses. Bilateral basal crackles, 2+ bilateral pedal edema, and mild hepatomegaly are also present. Neurologic examination shows decreased light touch and vibration sense in the feet, with decreased knee and ankle reflexes bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation shows normal blood counts. Deficiency of which of the following nutrients is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?

A microbiologist performs a genetic experiment in which cultures of Escherichia coli are treated with a chemical that induces a high frequency of mutations. Individual bacterial colonies are isolated to identify a mutant strain that lacks a specific enzyme involved in DNA replication. This specific enzyme is responsible for removing short fragments of RNA that are base paired to the DNA template. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this strain of E coli?

A research scientist studying the metabolic pathways that contribute to obesity, feeds experimental animals a high-carbohydrate, high-protein diet for a prolonged period. A sample of liver tissue is then obtained from the animals, and the activity of various enzymes involved in fatty acid metabolism is measured and recorded. It is determined that beta-oxidation of fatty acids is inhibited within these cells because of the diet. An increase in which of the following substances is most likely responsible for the observed effect?

A 68-year-old man with a long history of using chewing tobacco comes to the office for follow up of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the oral cavity. A month ago, the patient was diagnosed with SCC of the left lateral tongue. He underwent resection, the surgical specimen showed clear margins, and he started additional treatment. The patient recently noticed a second ulcerative lesion on the right lateral tongue. Biopsy is performed and it also shows SCC. The second tumor most likely arose from which of the following mechanisms?

A 33-year-old woman comes to the office due to intermittent dizziness. The patient describes a sensation of severe spinning accompanied by intense nausea that lasts 1-2 hours. She feels unsteady during these episodes and has to lie down with her eyes closed for relief. She also hears a "mechanical humming" sound in in her right ear during these episodes. The patient has no associated headaches, ear pain, or ear discharge. On examination, air conduction is greater than bone conduction in both ears. When the base of a tuning fork is placed against her forehead, the sound is heard more prominently in the left ear. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Optic nerve of the right eye
Parasympathetic innervation of the left eye
Parasympathetic innervation of the right eye
Sympathetic innervation of the right eye

questions.text: 32-year-old woman comes to the office for routine check up. Physical examination is unremarkable except for anisocoria. Pupillary examination findings in normal, bright, and dim light are shown in the image below. This patient's pupillary abnormality is likely due to a defect in which of the following pathways?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Parasympathetic innervation of the right eye

questions.text: 14-year-old boy comes to the office due to right ear pain, pruritus, and discharge over the past week. He has had no cold symptoms, hearing loss, dizziness, or tinnitus. The patient returned yesterday from a a 2-week vacation at Goa, where he swam daily. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 75/min. Manipulation of the right ear during otoscopy elicits pain. There is prominent swelling and erythema of the ear canal with purulent and crusty debris. The tympanic membrane appears normal and has normal mobility. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this patient's current condition?

A 60-year-old patient complains of decreased distant vision but he does not use spectacles for near vision. The image of his ocular examination is given below. What is this type of refractive error called?

A 34-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to severe headache. The patient describes unbearable, throbbing pain around his right eye that awakened him. Over the past week, he has had several similar episodes, which spontaneously resolved after 20-30 minutes. On physical examination, he appears restless and paces in the room. There is mild conjunctival injection and miosis of the right eye. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current symptoms?

62-year-old man comes for the evaluation of jaundice. Medical history is significant for uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and morbid obesity. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. BMl is 47 kg/m2.  Laboratory studies reveal elevated transaminases. A  liver biopsy is obtained, and trichrome staining shows the following. Which of the following cells is directly responsible for the histologic finding indicated by the arrow?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stellate (Ito) cells

 

  • Hepatic stellate (Ito) cells, located in the space of Disse, normally store vitamin A.
  • In chronic liver injury (eg, NAFLD/NASH, alcohol, hepatitis), stellate cells are activated by cytokines from Kupffer cells → transform into myofibroblast-like cells → secrete collagen → fibrosis/cirrhosis.
  • The trichrome stain highlights collagen deposition = hallmark of fibrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholangiocytes: Epithelial cells of bile ducts; involved in cholestatic diseases, not fibrosis.

 

Option B. Hepatocytes: Undergo ballooning degeneration & necrosis but do not produce collagen directly.

 

Option C. Kupffer cells: Liver macrophages; release cytokines (eg, TGF-β) that activate stellate cells but are not the direct source of fibrosis.

questions.text:
35-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of weakness, fatigue, and pallor. Physical examination is unremarkable except for conjunctival pallor. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Haemoglobin: 7.2 g/dL

 

Mean corpuscular volume: 90 fL

 

Reticulocytes: 0.1%

 

Platelets: 280,000 /uL

 

Leukocyte count: 6,700 cells/uL

 

Iron studies and serum B12 and folic acid levels are within normal limits. Bone marrow biopsy shows absence of erythroid precursors but preserved myeloid and megakaryocytic elements. Further workup would most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymic tumor

 

  • The patient has pure red cell aplasia (PRCA), characterized by anemia with low reticulocyte count, normal white blood cells and platelets, and bone marrow showing absent erythroid precursors but preserved myeloid and megakaryocytic lineages.
  • PRCA can be secondary to thymoma (thymic tumor), an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies or T cells suppress erythroid precursors.
  • Other malignancies listed are not commonly associated with PRCA.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Primarily causes anemia through chronic disease or bleeding but is not commonly associated with pure red cell aplasia or selective erythroid precursor absence.

 

Option B. Renal cell carcinoma: Known for producing erythropoietin and causing polycythemia rather than anemia; it is not typically linked with isolated red cell aplasia.

 

Option D. Cerebellar hemangioblastoma: Associated with von Hippel-Lindau disease and can lead to polycythemia due to ectopic erythropoietin production, not isolated anemia or red cell aplasia.

 

The image below shows THYMUS TUMOR on CT [likely suggestive of THYMOMA]

questions.text: 38-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to vomiting blood. After appropriate resuscitation measures, he undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, which reveals a bleeding duodenal ulcer. During hospital day 2, the patient develops decreased urine output. Serum creatinine rises to 3.0 mg/dL from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL. Renal biopsy shows patchy epithelial necrosis of the tubules, intratubular casts. Supportive care is provided. Several days later, his urine output significantly increases, and serum creatinine levels decline. Over the next few days, this patient is at highest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypokalemia

 

During recovery phase of ATN, patients develop polyuria due to impaired tubular reabsorption. This causes massive potassium loss → hypokalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperphosphatemia: Seen in initial oliguric phase, not recovery phase.

 

Option C. Metabolic acidosis: More likely in maintenance phase.

 

Option D. Volume overload: Occurs in oliguric phase, not diuretic recovery phase.

questions.text: Which of the following would be the expected physical examination finding over the right lower chest?
Which of the following is not a common feature of ABPA?
Which of the following does not cause hardness of water?

On world health day, 4 senior faculty from various departments sit in front of audience to talk about a topic. The director of hospital welcome audience and introduces everyone. There is no specific agenda, no order of speaking, and no set speech. In the end, audience is invited to take part. Identify this method of communication:

A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department unconscious after a motor vehicle accident. NCCT is shown here.  A branch of which of the following arteries is most likely severed in this patient?
All of the following are true about endotoxin except:
Identify the plant shown below?

A 57-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to lethargy and altered mental status. His family suspects a suicide attempt. Medical history is significant for dilated cardiomyopathy and major depressive disorder. On arrival, blood pressure is 76/46 mm Hg, pulse is 38/min, and respirations are 16/min. Pupils are 3mm and reactive. Oropharynx is normal. Examination shows bilateral wheezing. There is no peripheral edema. Capillary refill is 3 seconds. There is no diaphoresis. Which of the following categories of medication did this patient most likely ingest?

choices.text: Due to sulph-meth-hemoglobin accumulation and formation
It is associated with a case of electrical burns

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the image given below?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Due to sulph-meth-hemoglobin accumulation and formation

questions.text:
Arrange the following phases of cardiac cycle in sequential order from systole to diastole:

 

1. S1

2. S4

3. y descent

4. R wave
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4-1-3-2

 

Events given:

 

  1. S1 – first heart sound → due to closure of AV valves at the start of systole.
  2. S4 – atrial contraction sound (“atrial kick”) → occurs in late diastole, just before S1.
  3. y descent – fall in atrial pressure due to opening of AV valves and ventricular filling → early diastole.
  4. R wave – ECG ventricular depolarization → precedes ventricular systole, occurs just before S1.

 

Correct Sequence:

 

  • R wave (4) → ventricular depolarization → onset of systole.
  • S1 (1) → closure of AV valves → marks start of ventricular systole.
  • y descent (3) → rapid ventricular filling → early diastole.
  • S4 (2) → atrial contraction at end of diastole (presystolic).

 

So, sequence = 4 → 1 → 3 → 2

 

MNEMONIC : Pa4 QRS 1Cx T2dn v3y

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child was presented with a past of persistent cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling, who had experienced comparable symptoms, passed away a few years earlier. Tests including the sweat chloride test and CFTR gene analysis were conducted and cystic fibrosis was diagnosed. What will happen to the transport of Chloride ions in sweat gland and pancreatic ducts respectively?

What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided?

1. Disrupted cell membrane

2. Induces inflammation

3. Swelling of the cell

4. Can be seen physiologically

choices.text: Incomplete closure of anterior abdominal wall

questions.text:
A 2-week-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents for evaluation of his umbilicus. The parents report that since the umbilical cord stump separated 2 days ago, there has been serous pale drainage from the umbilicus that increases when the patient cries. He is exclusively breastfed and continues to have normal wet diapers and stool output.

 

Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Hemoglobin: 14 g/dL

 

Platelets: 240,000/mm3

 

TLC: 11,000/mm3

 

Neutrophils: 60%

 

Lymphocytes: 32%

 

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's umbilical findings?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Persistence of allantois remnant

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of exertional dyspnea and dry cough for 8 months. Oxygen saturation on room air while lying down is 96% and drops to 88% after 6 minutes of walking. Examination shows fine crackles in both lower lungs. Chest x-ray reveals reticular densities in both lung fields. Lung biopsy shows an infiltration of inflammatory cells, predominantly lymphocytes, as well as poorly formed noncaseating granulomas and moderate alveolar septal fibrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

 

The presence of lymphocytic infiltration, noncaseating granulomas, and fibrosis with exertional desaturation suggests hypersensitivity pneumonitis due to repeated antigen exposure. 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: Characterized by reversible airway obstruction, not fibrosis or granulomas. 

 

Option B. Chronic bronchitis: A clinical diagnosis with mucus hypersecretion, not granulomatous inflammation. 

 

Option D. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Usually shows usual interstitial pneumonia pattern without granulomas.

questions.text: Which of the following opioids is an antagonist at ‘µ’ and a complete agonist at ‘k’ receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pentazocine

 

  • Pentazocine → It is a mixed agonist–antagonist opioid.

    • Acts as an antagonist (or weak partial agonist) at µ receptors, hence less risk of respiratory depression and euphoria.
    • Acts as a complete agonist at κ receptors, producing analgesia, sedation, and dysphoria.
    • Clinically used for moderate pain but limited due to psychotomimetic effects (hallucinations, dysphoria).

     

Partial agonist: Buprenorphine

 

Mixed agonist/antagonist: Nalbuphine, Pentazocine, Butorphanol

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for a yearly physical examination. The patient feels well but is worried that she has not yet started puberty. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), blood pressure is 152/91 mmHg, pulse is 75/min, and respirations are 18/ min. Physical examination is significant for a lack of secondary sexual characteristics; a blind vagina is noted on pelvic examination. Laboratory studies reveal hypokalemia and low testosterone and estradiol levels. Cytogenetic analysis shows a 46, XY karyotype. This patient most likely has deficiency of which of the following enzymes?
Which of the subsequent options is non-essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome?

A 24-year-old G2 at 28 weeks is brought to the emergency after being found unconscious at home by her mother. She is disoriented on arrival and her BP is 180/110 mmHg and 4 + proteinuria. On arrival at the emergency, she has a tonic-clonic seizure which resolves with MgSO4 administration. Once the patient is stabilized, she undergoes caesarean delivery for fetal distress. Post-partum, the below MRI is done. What is the most likely finding on imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome

 

  • The case is classic for eclampsia: pregnant woman with hypertension, proteinuria, seizures.
  • The MRI shows bilateral symmetrical areas of hyperintensity in the posterior cerebral hemispheres (parieto-occipital regions), most characteristic of PRES.
  • PRES is associated with eclampsia and presents with headache, altered mental status, seizures, and visual disturbances. MRI usually shows vasogenic edema—seen as high signal in posterior regions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subdural hematoma, Option B. Parenchymal hemorrhage, Option C. Subarachnoid hemorrhage: Would show focal or diffuse hyperintensity in different locations, not typically as bilateral posterior edema.

choices.text: Reduced R-time, increased angle, increased MA, increased LY30
Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, decreased LY30
Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30
Reduced R-time, decreased angle, increased MA, decreased LY30

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with sepsis and purpura fulminans. Thromboelastography (TEG) is ordered to assess the patient's clotting profile. Which of the following TEG tracings is most consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prolonged R-time, decreased angle, decreased MA, increased LY30

 

  • The patient with sepsis and purpura fulminans is likely experiencing disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • In DIC, thromboelastography (TEG) typically shows:
    • Prolonged R-time: due to coagulation factor consumption leading to delayed clot initiation.
    • Increased angle: fibrinolysis may initially cause rapid clot formation before consumption.
    • Decreased maximum amplitude (MA): due to platelet dysfunction or decreased platelet count.
    • Increased LY30: indicating increased fibrinolysis and clot breakdown.

 

Other tracings do not fit the complex coagulopathy seen in sepsis-induced DIC with purpura fulminans.

questions.text: Identify the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Barium meal

 

The image demonstrates a classic barium meal radiograph, with opacification of the stomach and proximal duodenum, outlining the gastric contour and first part of the small intestine. The study is typically performed to assess the stomach and duodenum for ulcers, masses, or other pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BMFT (Barium meal follow-through): Would include more distal small bowel (jejunum/ileum) opacification after barium passes through, not limited to stomach and duodenum.

 

Option C. Barium enteroclysis: Involves direct infusion of barium into the small intestine and demonstrates detailed small bowel loops, which are not seen here.

questions.text: Identify the artery marked by red arrow:

choices.text: Cefazolin is a first generation parenteral cephalosporin
Cefixime has poor activity against Staph aureus
Cefoxitin has no activity against anaerobes

questions.text: All are true about cephalosporins except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Cefoxitin has no activity against anaerobes

questions.text: The following device is used for all of the following indications except:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair with respect to its nerve supply of the marked structures in the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal nerve

 

The muscle marked by C is Geniohyoid , supplied by hypoglossal nerve via C1 cervical root.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial nerve: Platysma – Supplied by Facial nerve

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: Digastric[ant belly] – Supplied by Mandibular nerve[V3]

 

Option D. Hypoglossal nerve: Supplied by Hypoglossal nerv

questions.text: Seven hours after undergoing left hip arthroplasty for chronic hip pain, a 67-year-old woman reports a prickling sensation in her left anteromedial thigh and lower leg. Neurologic examination shows left leg strength 3/5 on hip flexion and 2/5 on knee extension. Patellar reflex is decreased on the left. Sensation to pinprick and light touch are decreased on the anteromedial left thigh as well as medial lower leg. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Femoral nerve injury

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and decreased urine output for 2 weeks. He has not been to the physician for many years and takes no medications. Serum studies show a urea nitrogen concentration of 42 mg/dL and a creatinine concentration of 2.3 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows heavy proteinuria. A photomicrograph of a section of a kidney biopsy specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of lower leg weakness, swallowing difficulty, and drooling of saliva. He has not yet received any childhood vaccinations. Two days after admission, the patient develops shortness of breath. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 64%. Despite resuscitative efforts, the patient dies of respiratory failure. At autopsy, examination of the spinal cord shows destruction of the anterior horn cells. Neurological examination of this patient would have most likely shown which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyporeflexia

 

  • Anterior horn cells = lower motor neurons (LMN).
  • Damage leads to LMN signs: muscle weakness, hypotonia, fasciculations, hyporeflexia/areflexia.
  • Classical for poliomyelitis (unvaccinated child, anterior horn cell destruction).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive Babinski sign: Indicates UMN lesion (corticospinal tract damage), not LMN.

 

Option B. Clasp knife spasticity: Also a feature of UMN lesions due to loss of inhibitory control.

 

Option D. Sensory loss: Sensory pathways remain intact in polio → no sensory deficit.

choices.text: Pruritus and flushing of the skin

questions.text: A 53-year-old man with hyperlipidemia comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. His home medications include acetaminophen and atorvastatin. Serum studies show elevated total cholesterol and triglyceride concentrations. A drug that activates the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha is added to his existing therapy. This patient is most likely to develop which of the following drug-related adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reddish-brown discoloration of urine

 

This occurs due to myopathy or rhabdomyolysis, a known serious adverse effect of fibrates (PPAR-alpha activators) especially when combined with statins like atorvastatin. The muscle breakdown releases myoglobin, which colors the urine reddish-brown.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Waxing and waning confusion: This is not associated with fibrates; it suggests neurological causes unrelated to this drug class.

 

Option C. Pruritus and flushing of the skin: These are typical side effects of niacin, not fibrates.

 

Option D. Acutely swollen and painful joint: While fibrates can elevate uric acid levels increasing gout risk, this is less common than rhabdomyolysis and urine discoloration.

choices.text: Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli
Gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci
Gram-negative spiral bacteria visible on dark-field microscopy
Gram-positive, bacitracin-sensitive cocci

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 6-hour history of severe eye pain and blurry vision. He wears soft contact lenses and has not removed them for 2 days. Ophthalmologic examination shows a deep corneal ulcer, severe conjunctival injection, and purulent discharge on the right. Treatment with topical ciprofloxacin is initiated. A culture of the ocular discharge is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacilli

questions.text: The World Health Organization suggests the use of a new rapid diagnostic test for the diagnosis of malaria in resource-limited settings. The new test has a sensitivity of 70% and a specificity of 90% compared to the gold standard test (blood smear). The validity of the new test is evaluated at a satellite health center by testing 200 patients with a positive blood smear and 150 patients with a negative blood smear. How many of the tested individuals are expected to have a false negative result?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 60

 

False negatives occur among those who truly have malaria (blood-smear positive) and are missed by the test. 

 

Sensitivity = 70% means the test correctly identifies 70% of true positives and misses 30%.

 

Remember the formulae:

 

Here,

 

For 200 true positives, 30% × 200 = 60 false negatives. So 60 individuals with positive blood smears will test negative on the rapid test.

questions.text: A previously healthy 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of confusion for 2 hours. His wife reports that he fell and hit his head while changing a ceiling light the previous evening. On arrival, he is unconscious. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8ºF), pulse is 54/min, respirations are 8/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 198/106 mm Hg. The right pupil is dilated and fixed; the left pupil is round and reactive to light. There is extension of the extremities to painful stimuli. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A mannitol infusion is begun. A noncontrast CT scan of the brain shows herniation of the right medial temporal lobe. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right-sided hemiplegia

 

This patient has uncal (transtentorial) herniation due to head trauma → temporal lobe compresses against tentorium cerebelli.

 

Key features:

 

  • Dilated, fixed ipsilateral pupil → compression of ipsilateral CN III (oculomotor nerve).
  • Hemiplegia on the same side (ipsilateral hemiplegia) → due to compression of contralateral cerebral peduncle against tentorium (Kernohan’s notch phenomenon → “false localizing sign”).
  • Cushing’s triad seen here: hypertension + bradycardia + irregular breathing.
  • Decerebrate posturing (extension to pain) suggests midbrain/upper pons involvement.

 

Thus, the most likely finding is right-sided hemiplegia (same side as the dilated pupil).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bilateral spasticity: Suggests diffuse upper motor neuron lesions (eg, advanced ALS, spinal cord injury), not acute herniation.

 

Option C. Bilateral lower limb paralysis: More typical of anterior cerebral artery infarction, not uncal herniation.

 

Option D. Right eye esotropia and elevation: Seen in CN VI (abducens) palsy, but here the oculomotor nerve is affected → causing down & out eye with ptosis and mydriasis, not esotropia.

choices.text: Aortic valve cusp and interventricular septum
Aortic valve cusp and papillary muscle
Mitral valve leaflet and interventricular septum

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is evaluated due to an episode of syncope. He was jogging when he felt light-headed and passed out, but he did not sustain a head injury. The patient has had 2 similar episodes of light-headedness while jogging. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. His father died suddenly at age 30. On physical examination, the patient has a harsh systolic murmur. The lungs are clear to auscultation. This patient's symptoms are most likely explained by left ventricular outflow obstruction created by which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Mitral valve leaflet and interventricular septum

questions.text: A 34-year-old female is hospitalized with progressive exertional dyspnea, lower extremity edema and cough. She also describes frequent nocturnal episodes of breathlessness and recent hoarseness. Auscultation reveals loud first and second heart sounds and a mid-diastolic rumble best heard at the cardiac apex. This patient's hoarseness is most likely caused by:

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician with jaundice and pallor. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. Laboratory studies show anemia, reticulocytosis, and increased indirect bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear is shown. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased MCHC

 

  • The patient's presentation of anemia, reticulocytosis, increased indirect bilirubin, and the peripheral smear showing spherocytes suggests hereditary spherocytosis.
  • In hereditary spherocytosis, red blood cells are sphere-shaped and have increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) due to decrease in cell surface area.
  • Additional findings typically include:
    • Decreased haptoglobin (not increased) due to hemolysis.
    • Increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) (not decreased) from cell breakdown.
    • Negative Coombs test because it's a hereditary membrane defect, not autoimmune hemolysis.

questions.text: Identify the nerve injured:
What is the likely genetic abnormality in the following patient?

A 65-year-old man comes to the OPD due to advanced prostate cancer with bone metastases. For the last 4 months, he has been treated with a GnRH agonist, which has significantly reduced his bone pain. However, the patient now reports discomfort at the anterior chest wall. Physical examination reveals bilateral, mildly tender enlargement of the breast tissue behind the nipple-areolar complex. Early initiation of which of the following medications would be most appropriate for preventing this patient's breast symptoms?

choices.text: Packed Red Blood Cells (PRBC) - Bottom of centrifuge

questions.text: All of the following are correct about components of blood transfusion except:
questions.solution: Ans. D) Albumin - Sediment of centrifuge

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis based on the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aneurysmal bone cyst

 

The radiograph shows an expansile, eccentric lytic lesion in the metaphysis of the proximal tibia with thin cortical margins. This is characteristic of an aneurysmal bone cyst (ABC), which typically affects children and young adults. ABCs present with rapid onset pain and swelling and often demonstrate a “soap-bubble” appearance on imaging due to multiple blood-filled cavities.

 

Other Options
 

Option A. Giant cell tumour: Usually arises in the epiphysis of long bones in adults and displays a more aggressive, subarticular appearance; not typically seen in children or metaphyseal locations.

 

 

Option B. Osteoblastoma: A rare benign bone tumour, often larger and found in the spine or posterior elements, not metaphyseal long bones. 

 

 

Option D. Osteoid osteoma: Presents as a small radiolucent nidus with surrounding sclerosis, commonly in the cortex of diaphyseal bone, and is associated with night pain relieved by NSAIDs.

questions.text:
In which of the following vessels will the blood flow get affected if one puts a temporary clamp near the origin of the common hepatic artery?

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Right gastric
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Right gastroepiploic
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Replaced left hepatic
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Left gastroepiploic
  5. ﻿﻿﻿Left hepatic
  6. Superior pancreaticoduodenal
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 5, 6

 

To answer this question, we need to understand the branches of the common hepatic artery (CHA) and which downstream vessels would have their blood flow affected if a clamp is placed near its origin.

 

The common hepatic artery (CHA) is a branch of the celiac trunk and gives rise to the following major branches:

 

1. Proper hepatic artery, which then gives:

  • Right hepatic artery

→ Cystic artery

  • Left hepatic artery
  • Occasionally, right gastric artery arises here

2. Gastroduodenal artery, which gives:

  • Right gastroepiploic artery
  • Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery

 

Correct options:

 

1. Right gastric artery – Usually arises from the proper hepatic artery, a branch of CHA → Affected

 

2. Right gastroepiploic artery – Branch of gastroduodenal artery, which arises from CHA → Affected

 

5. Left hepatic artery – Usually a branch of proper hepatic artery → Affected 

 

6.Superior pancreaticoduodenal artery – Branch of gastroduodenal artery, which comes from CHA → Affected

 

Incorrect options:

 

3. Replaced left hepatic artery – If replaced, this means it arises not from CHA → Not affected

 

4. Left gastroepiploic artery – Arises from splenic artery, not from CHA → Not affected

questions.text: The caecum is found to be placed below the stomach and is midline. Which of the following abnormalities must have taken place while rotation of the gut?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mixed Rotation 

 

During embryological development, the midgut rotates 270° counterclockwise around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA).

 

  • Normal rotation: places the caecum in the right lower quadrant.
  • Mixed rotation: part of the midgut rotates normally, while another part malrotates. This can result in abnormal positioning such as the caecum lying below the stomach, in the midline.
    • It is a combination of malrotation and nonrotation features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malrotation:

 

  • Incomplete rotation of midgut.
  • Caecum may lie in subhepatic region (right upper quadrant), not below stomach in midline.

 

Option B. Nonrotation:

 

  • Midgut fails to rotate the final 180°.
  • Caecum ends up on the left side of abdomen, not midline.

 

Option C. Reverse rotation:

 

  • Midgut rotates in the clockwise direction instead of counterclockwise.
  • Leads to duodenum lying anterior to SMA and transverse colon posterior to SMA.
  • Not associated with caecum lying below the stomach.

questions.text: A young female patient complains of low back pain radiating to the right hip, back of the thigh, leg, and ankle after an intense workout of lifting some heavy weights. MRI shows the following finding. Which function will be weak here?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EHL

 

Weakness of the Extensor Hallucis Longus (EHL) muscle is most commonly associated with L5 nerve root compression, which occurs frequently in lumbar disc herniation presenting as unilateral lower limb radiculopathy. The EHL is responsible for extending the big toe and assisting in dorsiflexion of the foot; its involvement produces difficulty in toe extension and clearing the foot during gait. This presentation strongly fits the described clinical scenario of pain radiating along the L5 dermatome, after heavy lifting, with classic MRI findings of disc pathology impinging the L5 root. Since EHL weakness is sensitive for L5 radiculopathy, focusing on this muscle in neurological exam aids localization and management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hip flexion: Hip flexion is primarily controlled by the iliopsoas muscle, innervated by L2–L3 nerve roots. Compression of L5 (as depicted by MRI and clinical findings) would not produce significant weakness in hip flexion.

 

Option B. Ankle dorsiflexion: Ankle dorsiflexion is mainly performed by the tibialis anterior muscle, predominantly L4 innervation, though some contribution from L5. Isolated L5 root compression more typically produces weakness of EHL rather than complete loss of ankle dorsiflexion, which is more severe in broader lesions.

 

Option D. Ankle plantar flexion: Plantar flexion of the ankle is executed by muscles like gastrocnemius and soleus, innervated by the S1 and S2 roots. L5 root compression does not cause plantar flexion weakness; S1 involvement would be required.

questions.text: Identify the ethmoidal cells shown in the CT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Agger nasi

 

  • The CT scan shows air cells located anterior and superior to the nasolacrimal duct, marked by arrows.
  • These are Agger nasi cells, which are the most anterior ethmoidal air cells.
  • They are located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate and are important surgically, as they form the anterior boundary of the frontal recess.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bulla ethmoidalis: 

 

  • The largest and most constant anterior ethmoidal cell.
  • Lies posterior to the uncinate process and forms part of the lateral nasal wall.

 

 

Option B. Concha bullosa:

 

  • Pneumatization of the middle turbinate itself.
  • Seen as an air-filled cavity inside the turbinate, not as anterior ethmoid cells.

 

 

Option D. Haller cell:

 

  • Infraorbital ethmoid air cells, located along the floor of the orbit near the maxillary sinus roof.

choices.text: 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
7 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line
3 cm below the right costal margin at the mid-axillary line
7 cm below the right costal margin at the mid-clavicular line

questions.text: Palmer's point is the point where you would insert the Veress needle. Identify it:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line

 

Palmer's point is located 3 cm below the left costal margin at the mid-clavicular line. This is the site where the Veress needle is inserted (typically when the umbilical site is contraindicated). It is preferred because it offers a relatively safe upper left quadrant site free of major vascular and visceral structures. The other options either are incorrectly placed or pose higher risk, hence are not standard sites for Veress needle insertion.


Various other points used for Veeres needle insertion are pictured below :

questions.text: Identify the X-linked disorder from the options below:

questions.text: A patient develops gastroenteritis after eating raw seafood. Culture shows the Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar. Which statement about the organism is correct?

choices.text: Study is invalid due to low p-value

questions.text: The histological image of a 45 year old male with colitis is shown. Which of the following treatment regimens is most appropriate?

questions.text: Identify the cylinder:

An obese diabetic patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. His pH is 7.2, urine is positive for ketones and glucose, and blood glucose is 130 mg/dL. Which drug is most likely responsible?

It is useful in difficult airways

questions.text: During intubation, the anesthetist uses the (Backward, upward, Rightward Pressure) BURP maneuver. Which of the following statements is correct about this technique?
questions.solution: Ans. D) It is useful in difficult airways

choices.text: Increased DLCO with increased A-a gradient
Increased DLCO with decreased A-a gradient
Decreased DLCO with decreased A-a gradient
Decreased DLCO with increased A-a gradient

questions.text: In a patient with advanced sarcoidosis affecting the lungs, what is the most expected finding on investigation?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Decreased DLCO with increased A-a gradient

questions.text: During an online consultation, a patient says, “I’m doing finertends” and is known to use made-up words frequently. What type of thought disorder does this represent?
Microscopy of cervical secretions shows the following seen in a particular menstrual phase. What would vaginal cytology likely reveal in this phase?
A 56-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes has marfanoid features and pheochromocytoma. Which hypoglycemic drug should be avoided?

14-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother because she has not started menstruating. Height is at the 15th percentile and weight is at the 20th percentile for age. There is no breast development or axillary hair. Pelvic examination reveals normal external female genitalia and no pubic hair. Ultrasound confirms the presence of a uterus. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
A 46-year-old man presents with fever, joint pains, fatigue. His tests show HCV RNA and anti-HCV IgG positive. What is the best drug regimen?

choices.text: Wait for an hour for spontaneous labor

questions.text: You are examining a multigravida in the second stage of labor for the past two hours. On examination, contractions are adequate, the cervix is fully dilated with the head at station 0 with moulding 2+ and caput 2+. The sagittal suture is in the right occipito-transverse position. The fetal heart rate is 140 beats/minute. Which of the following is carried out for the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Lower segment caesarean section

questions.text: Identify the drug that is both a phosphodiesterase 3 inhibitor and increases calcium binding to troponin C used in heart failure?
What is the lifetime prevalence of schizophrenia in a monozygotic twin of a patient with schizophrenia?

A 32-year-old woman, gravida 3 para 2, at 38 weeks gestation comes to the hospital due to contractions. She had a cesarean delivery for breech presentation at 39 weeks gestation in her second pregnancy. Blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, and respirations are 22/min. Fetal heart rate tracing shows moderate variability, multiple accelerations, and no decelerations. Uterine contractions are regular and occur every 4 minutes. The cervix is 6 cm dilated and 60% effaced, and the fetal vertex is at 0 station. After 2 hours, the patient is suddenly restless and has intense lower abdominal pain. Fetal heart monitoring shows recurrent late decelerations. On pelvic examination, there is moderate vaginal bleeding, the cervix is 6 cm dilated and 60% effaced, and the fetal vertex is at -3 station. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
Which of the following does not provide passive immunity?

A middle-aged obese individual with elevated liver enzymes is diagnosed with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and moderate-to-advanced liver fibrosis. Which recently approved medication is indicated for this condition?

choices.text: Blisters form in the suprabasal layer

questions.text: 75-year-old woman develops tense, itchy bullae and blisters. Immunofluorescence shows a linear pattern and histopathology is shown. Which of the following is true regarding the diagnosis?

A 35-year-old multiparous woman has stress urinary incontinence (SUI) that persists despite performing Kegel exercises for six months. Which medication can be used as part of her conservative management?

An intraoperative frozen section has been sent by a surgeon to the pathology laboratory. A special stain has been applied by the pathologist as empty looking areas were found after routine staining resulting in inability to make any diagnosis. Identify the special stain used?
A child presents with severe freckling and sunburn after brief sun exposure. Which DNA repair defect is responsible for the disorder?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Defective Nucleotide Excision Repair

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman receives 1 unit of packed RBCs for PPH. Two hours later, she develops fever, chills, and mild breathlessness. There is no jaundice, dark urine, or hypotension. Cardiovascular exam is normal. What is the most likely cause of this transfusion reaction?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Antibodies to donor WBCs

questions.text: Which of the following substances is used for sample collection in a tube for blood alcohol concentration measurement?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Sodium fluoride + Potassium oxalate

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with focal seizures is prescribed ezogabine. What is the drug’s mechanism of action?

Which of the following features is most consistent with hyponatremia due to SIADH?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Euvolemia, UNa >40 mmol/L, Uosm >100 mOsm/kg

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs are correctly matched regarding the methylene blue 3-swab test findings and their interpretations?

  1. The uppermost swab gets wet but not stained – Ureterovaginal fistula
  2. The uppermost swab gets stained – Vesicovaginal fistula
  3. The middle swab gets stained – Vesicovaginal fistula
  4. The lowermost swab gets stained – Urethrovaginal fistula

questions.solution: Ans. C) Final cause of death is assigned solely by a single expert physician

choices.text: Axillary and pubic hair is present

It involves a return visit for follow-up

It includes explaining all aspects of the decision

questions.text: All are true regarding the GATHER approach except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) It is used mainly for psychiatric therapy sessions

According to which of the following doctrines is the doctor not negligent in the above-said case?
